content: The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" is also known as the "Anti-counterfeiting Amendments Act of 2004." It includes provisions prohibiting trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or packaging for various types of works, with penalties of fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or packaging for various types of works, with penalties of fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. The term 'illicit label' is defined as a genuine certificate or labeling component used by the copyright owner to verify that a product is not counterfeit or infringing any copyright. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distributing counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works without authorization, with penalties of fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. This includes falsifying genuine certificates or licensing documents to designate a higher number of licensed users or copies than authorized by the copyright owner, unless used for monitoring distribution channels. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distributing counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works without authorization. This includes falsifying genuine certificates or licensing documents, unless used for monitoring distribution channels. The act defines terms like "documentation or packaging" and "counterfeit documentation or packaging." The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distributing counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works without authorization. This includes affixing counterfeit labels to various copyrighted materials such as sound recordings, computer programs, literary works, and visual art. The act also includes provisions for counterfeit or illicit labels and the equipment used to manufacture them. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits distributing counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works without authorization. This includes affixing counterfeit or illicit labels to copyrighted materials and the equipment used to produce them. Civil remedies allow copyright owners to bring a civil action in court for violations of the act. The court may grant injunctions, order impounding of articles, and award attorney fees, damages, and profits to the injured party for violations of distributing counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works without authorization. The injured party is entitled to recover actual damages and profits from a violator for a violation of distributing counterfeit labels or packaging for copyrighted works without authorization. The court calculates actual damages by multiplying the value of the counterfeit items by the number of items involved. The value of a copyrighted item is determined by its retail value, such as sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, and literary works. The retail value of authorized copies of copyrighted works, including computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, pictorial/graphic/sculptural works, and visual art, is used to determine damages for violations. The injured party can choose to receive statutory damages ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 per violation instead of actual damages and profits. The court may triple the damages for subsequent violations. The court may award statutory damages ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 for each violation of subsection (a). Damages can be tripled for subsequent violations within 3 years. A civil action must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the violation. The item relating to section 2318 is amended to include trafficking in counterfeit labels, illicit labels, or counterfeit documentation or packaging. SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, or fair use under section 107 of Title 17. It also specifies that the amendments do not apply to electronic transmissions of genuine certificates or counterfeit labels under Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect fair use under section 107 of Title 17, United States Code, for genuine certificates, licensing documents, registration cards, labeling components, or documentation described in specific sections of Title 18, United States Code. SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the "Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act". SEC. 202. AMENDMENT TO TRADEMARK ACT OF 1946. Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided in connection with a domain name violation. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement in cases where false contact information is knowingly provided to domain name authorities. This does not limit what constitutes willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as per the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendment to Title 18, United States Code includes a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of felony offenses involving false registration of a domain name, doubling the maximum imprisonment or adding 7 years. The terms "falsely registers" and "domain name" are defined within the amendment. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend sentencing guidelines to ensure that penalties for felony offenses carried out online using a domain name with false contact information are stringent enough to deter such acts. Sentencing enhancements will be provided for those convicted of felony offenses involving knowingly providing false information. The Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for felony offenses involving knowingly providing false contact information to domain name authorities. The term "domain name" is defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 205. CONSTRUCTION. This title does not affect free speech or press rights related to domain name activities. Courts retain discretion in determining damages, relief, and terms of imprisonment for intellectual property rights infringement. TITLE III--COURTS. Additional court locations are added in Colorado and Northern District of New York. Section 85 of title 28, United States Code, amended to include "Colorado Springs," after "Boulder." Section 112(a) of title 28, United States Code, amended to include "Plattsburgh," after "Malone."
